item.question:
You want to remove the file -x from the directory listing shown in above exhibit.
Which of the following commands can you use to remove the file?
item.hint: It is not the shell that will consider <font face="monospace">-x</font> as a special item. Hence, escaping <font face="monospace">-x</font> for the shell will not have the desired effect. In this case you will need to make it clear to the command <font face="monospace">rm</font> that <font face="monospace">-x</font> should not be interpreted as an option.

item.question: Which of the following commands allows you to read the content of a directory?
item.hint: Many commands on UNIX/Linux are abbreviated. For example, the command <font face="monospace">cp</font> stands for <font face="monospace">copy</font>. By determining the full name of the command it usually makes it clear what action the command will perform when executed.

item.question: Which of the following is not stored in an inode?
item.hint: File names are only meant to make it easier for humans to handle files. The Operating System uses the inode numbers to handle the files.

item.question:
The textfile riddle.txt contains the content shown above.
Which line is returned when executing the following command?
grep '^M' riddle.txt
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">^</font> character will match at the beginning of a line.

item.question: What will be the result when you execute the commandline shown above?
item.choice: Error as <font face="monospace">sort</font> has no knowledge of <font face="monospace">-c</font>
Writes the list of logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font> and prints the amount of times a user is logged in to screen.
Writes the list of all logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font>.
Will first execute the command <font face="monospace">who</font>, then the command <font face="monospace">sort</font>, and after that the command <font face="monospace">uniq</font>.
item.correct_answer: Writes the list of all logged in users to the file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font>.
item.hint: In a so-called pipe-construction the commands are separated by the <font face="monospace">|</font> character. This will result in the output of the command left of the <font face="monospace">|</font> character be passed as input to the command right of the <font face="monospace">|</font> character. The <font face="monospace">></font> character will connect the output of the command to the file specified after the <font face="monospace">></font> character. However, there is only one stream of data. In other words, where will the output of the command <font face="monospace">sort</font> go to? The file <font face="monospace">namen.txt</font> of the command <font face="monospace">uniq</font>?
